docs.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Dr. Joel Potash made his monthly house call on an elderly man who had spent a year confined to bed, wasting away from kidney cancer that had spread to his bones. Dr. Potash was about to discuss the futility of further treatment, when the patient startled him with another suggestion: ''It's time to get this over with,'' the patient told Dr. Potash. ''I want you to assist me to die.''

headline.main: When a Healer Is Asked, 'Help Me Die'
headline.kicker: DOCTORS AND DEATH: A special report.

docs.abstract: Elisabeth Rosenthal, in special report Doctors and Death, contends that as judges and legislators mull over theoretical pros and cons of assisted suicide, physicians face very real and agonizing decisions on whether to prescribe lethal dose of sedative or to inject on request deadly narcotic; few issues have proved so divisive among doctors or so confusing to them individually; virtually ever major medical organization opposes physician-assisted suicide, but recent surveys have found that majority of practicing doctors favor legalizing practice and that, if it were legal, about third of them would help patients commit suicide; a few already have; some doctors comment; photos (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Southside, a Latino and Hasidic section of Williamsburg, sits on one edge of Brooklyn, a neighborhood staring out at the lights of Manhattan. It is a neighborhood of dying industry and full-blown poverty, a neighborhood of churches and shuls, of immigrants and their children. It is also a welfare neighborhood, and so it now feels a deep unease about the new welfare legislation and what it and similar local changes have done, and will mean.

headline.main: In a Pocket of Brooklyn Sewn by Welfare, an Unraveling

docs.abstract: Southside, a Hasidic and Latino part of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is poor and largely dependent on public assistance in one form or another, and it is beginning to feel a deep unease about how new Federal welfare law and similar local changes that will affect people's lives as well as local bodegas, discount stores, travel agencies and other modest businesses; effect can already been seen in tales of hardship and success and in decisions of business people and institutions that function on welfare money; photos; map (L)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton said today that like Vice President Al Gore, he might have asked supporters for money during telephone conversations from the White House but that he could not remember any specific calls. Presenting a doggedly genial but unapologetic defense of fund-raising for his re-election, the President said that he had always disliked making such calls but that he could have placed them legally.

headline.main: CLINTON DEFENDS 1996 FUND-RAISING BUT HITS SYSTEM

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, at White House news conf, gives doggedly genial but unapologetic defense of fund-raising for his re-election; says that like Vice Pres Gore, he might have asked supporters for money during telephone conversations from White House but that he could not remember any specific calls; says that he had always disliked making such calls but that he could have placed them legally; although he defends Gore's telephone calls, he adds that he agrees with Gore's decision to stop soliciting money from his White House office; Clinton also firmly defends Margaret A Williams, Hillary Rodham Clinton's chief of staff, who admitted this week that she accepted $50,000 check from contributor in First Lady's offices; asserts that no one at White House would ever accept such checks again and that he knows of no other instances when anyone had; photo (L)
